column4: I want to try Gentoo from within Ubuntu.  Would it be possible to resize my root partition to allow space for Gentoo or do you suggest another method?
if your CPU is recent enough to have virtualization extensions, virtualization wouldn't be that much slower
I'm not sure if it is recent enough, my CPU is an Intel Dual Core 2.1 Ghz
cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep model
model 15 - Intel Pentium Dual Core E2200 @ 2.20 Ghz
nope, no virtualization extensions on that one :(
so long as you're not using hibernation, you can re-use the same swap partition for two distributions
Thanks, good info
do you have permission to extract the file to that directory?
That was it, didn't use sudo to run the command
I often forget to do that
hehe, no problem
only when your unprivileged user doesn't have the rights to do whatever it is you're trying to do
which I admit is sort of a circular answer
how does one tell if sudo is neededfor a command?
I don't usually check rights before issuing any file commands
generally speaking, your user can do pretty much whatever it wants inside /home/<your user>. outside of that, pretty much everything else is owned by root or another system account.
the whole directory I created for gentoo is owned by root... I see that when I type "ls -l"
as it should be, if you're installing a base system. if you installed it as your user you would have serious issues.
appreciate the help :)
sure thing
